sen.j: 軍役（ぐんやく、ぐんえき）は、戦時、武士が主君に拠出すべく課せられる軍事力や兵糧その他である。
sen.e: Gunyaku was a military service and provisions that was imposed by the lord on a samurai retainer to offer in wartime.
Gunyaku was a military service and provisions that was imposed by the lord on a samurai retainer to offer in wartime.

sen.e: Gunyaku (also known as Guneki) was a military service and provisions that was imposed by the lord on a retainer to offer in wartime.

sen.j: 軍役は広義には民衆に課せられる夫役のうちの兵役なども含まれるが、狭義には封建制度における「御恩と奉公」の関係において、知行地の安堵（御恩）と引き替えに主君に軍事的奉公を行うことである。
sen.e: In a broad sense, gunyaku covered a meaning of conscription included in buyaku (the labor service) which was imposed on the people; but in a narrow sense, gunyaku meant samurai retainer's offering of a military service to the lord in exchange for ando (安堵, recognition and guarantee) (go-on, 御恩, debt) of ownership of chigyochi (fief) in the relationship of 'go-on to hoko (debts and service)' in the feudal system.

In a broad sense, gunyaku meant conscription which included buyaku (the labor service) that was imposed on the people; but in a narrow sense, gunyaku referred to a samurai retainer's offering of military service to the lord in exchange for ando (安堵, recognition and guarantee) (go-on, 御恩, debt) of ownership of chigyochi (fief) in the relationship of 'go-on to hoko (debts and service)' in the feudal system.

sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 中世の土地支配権は近世のような「一つの土地に一人の領主」は確立されておらず、その支配体系も近世のものよりずっと複雑であった。
sen.e: Sway over lands in the middle ages had not been evolved to 'one lord in one land' as in the Early-Modern period yet, and the swaying system was much more complicated than that of the Early-Modern ages.

Sway over lands in the middle ages had not been evolved to 'one lord in one land' as in the Early-Modern period yet, and the swaying system was much more complicated than that of the Early-Modern ages.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 土地には耕作権を意味する「作職」、年貢徴収請負権の「名主」、荘園領主への年貢納入を請け負う「地頭職」などが重層に存在し、さらに国衙や守護職が令制国単位で影響力を及ぼしていたため、武士の主従関係も一対一の単純なものであるとは限られていなかった。
sen.e: There was a multilayered structure of rights claimed for a land such as 'saku-shiki (the right of the cultivator)' which meant the right of cultivation, 'myoshu (landholder)' which meant the right of contracting to collect land taxes, and 'jito-shiki (the stewardship rights)' which was for contracting to pay the land taxes to shoen-ryoshu (the lord of the manor); besides, as kokuga (provincial government office) and shugoshoku (military governor) had influences on each ryoseikoku (province), master-servant relationships among samurai were not necessarily a simple one-to-one relationship.
sen.cmt: 「名主」myoshuは「名主職」myoshu-shiki (the rights of landholders to part of the produce)の誤りと思われますが、原文通りに訳しました。
sen.e: There was a multilayered structure of rights claimed for a land such as 'saku-shiki (the right of the cultivator)' which meant the right of cultivation, 'myoshu (landholder)' which referred to the right to collect land taxes, and 'jito-shiki (the stewardship rights)' which was for contracting to pay out land taxes to shoen-ryoshu (the lord of the manor); besides, as kokuga (provincial government office) and shugoshoku (military governor) possessed influence on each ryoseikoku (province), master-servant relationships among samurai were not necessarily a simple one-to-one relationship.

sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 武士はやがて荘園を蚕食していき、自らの土地支配を保証する実効力を持った有力な上層武士に、年貢に代わって軍役を負担することでその支配を確立していくようになった。
sen.e: After a while, samurai began encroaching shoen (manor in medieval Japan), and gradually established sway over shoen by paying influential higher ranking samurai who was able to warrant the samurai the sway over the land, in a military service instead of land tax.

After a while, samurai began encroaching shoen (manor in medieval Japan), and gradually established sway over shoen by paying an influential higher ranking samurai who was able to warrant the samurai the sway over the land, in a military service instead of land tax.
sen.cmt: Edited for flow
sen.e: After a while, samurai began encroaching the manors and gradually established contrrol over the manors by paying an influential higher ranking samurai, who was able to warrant the samurai the control over the land, in a military service instead of land tax.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 平安時代には武士の支配を法的に保証するのは荘園領主たる「領家」「本所」であり、開発領主たちはその所領を孜々として寄進し、名簿（みょうぼ）を奉って子弟を近侍させ、猟官活動を行った。
sen.e: In the Heian period, 'ryoke' or 'honjo' which was the shoen-ryoshu legally warranted samurai the sway over shoen; on the other hand, kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) did office-seeking by assiduously contributing shoryo (territory), offering myobu (a certificate given to the leader with the retainer's name on it) and having had his sons be retainers.
sen.cmt: 名簿（みょうぼ）は、「みょうぶ」とも読むようです。インターネットではmyobuで検索すると、ここでの意味に該当する言葉がヒットします。
sen.e: In the Heian period, 'ryoke' or 'honjo' which was the shoen-ryoshu legally warranted samurai the sway over shoen; on the other hand, kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) did office-seeking by assiduously contributing shoryo (territory), offering myobu (a certificate given to the leader with the retainer's name on it) and had his sons be retainers.
sen.cmt: Edited for flow
sen.e: During the Heian period, the lord of the manor called 'ryoke' or 'honjo' legally warranted samurai the control over the manor; on the other hand, the local notables who actually developed the land did office-seeking by assiduously contributing their territory, offering a certificate given to the leader with the retainer's name on it and had his sons be retainers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一方で開発領主たちは国衙や郡衙から令制国住人として軍役を課せられ、在庁官人として出仕した。
sen.e: In the meantime, kaihatsu-ryoshu, as a resident of the ryoseikoku, was imposed to offer military service by kokuga or gunga (district government office) and presented himself for duty as Zaicho-kanjin (the local officials in Heian and Kamakura periods).

sen.j: 武士の軍役としてもっとも古い形はこれらの領家への近侍や国衙への出仕における軍事的奉仕であったと思われる。
sen.e: The oldest style of military service imposed on samurai supposed to have been military corvee when samurai served to the ryoke as a retainer or presented himself for duty at the kokuga.
The oldest style of military service imposed on samurai was supposed to have been military corvee when samurai served the ryoke as a retainer or presented himself for duty at the kokuga.

sen.j: やがて彼らの土地の保証は源氏、平家といった、貴種に連なる上級武家に委ねられ、下級、中級の武士は「給人」と呼ばれて、主君から恩給された土地の見返りに、平時、戦時における主君への軍事的奉仕を行う構造が出来上がった。
sen.e: Later, the higher ranking samurai families such as Minamoto clan or Taira family which had relationship with persons of noble birth were entrusted to warrant samurai the land, and a system was established in which middle and lower ranking samurai were called 'kyunin' and offered military services to the lord not only in peacetime but also in wartime in exchange for the land which the lord granted them as onkyu (stipend).

Later, the higher ranking samurai families such as Minamoto clan or Taira family which had relationships with persons of noble birth were entrusted to warrant samurai the land, and a system was established in which middle and lower ranking samurai were called 'kyunin' who offered military services to the lord not only in peacetime but also in wartime in exchange for the land which the lord granted them as onkyu (stipend).

sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ただし前述のごとく土地への影響力は重層構造であったため、在地領主は自らの土地を守るべく、将軍家のほか、有力公家、国守や守護、あるいは在地の有力武家にその安堵を求めることもあった。
sen.e: Since there was the multilayered structure of influences put on a land as mentioned above, zaichi-ryoshu (resident landholder) sometimes asked not only the shogunate but also influential court nobles, kokushu (governor of a province) or shugo (military governor), or resident influential samurai family for ando (安堵) of the ownership of the land, for the purpose of protecting the ownership of his land.

sen.j: 鎌倉期の幕府御家人に課せられた軍役は、大番役や追捕などであり、戦時には「いざ鎌倉」とはせ参じた。
sen.e: The military service imposed on bakufu-gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) in the Kamakura period included obanyaku (guard duty in Kyoto and Kamakura), tsuibu (to search and capture) and the like, and in a wartime, they rushed to the place, 'Iza Kamakura (To Kamakura with haste)'.
sen.cmt: 「追捕」は「追捕使」の誤りである可能性があります。

sen.j: 元寇では過重な軍役に比して所領の加増が少なかったことが鎌倉得宗への不満として蓄積し、鎌倉幕府滅亡の遠因になったと考えられる。

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)になると、各国の中小武士団は新たな源氏の棟梁、足利氏のほか、半済令以後勢力を蓄えた守護大名、南朝、北朝方の有力武家らに所領安堵を求めた。
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), small and medium bushidan (samurai warrior band) in provinces asked not only the new head of the government, Genji-descent Ashikaga clan, but also Shugo Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) which had increased its influence after hanzeirei (order allowing military governors, or Shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) was issued, influential samurai families on the side of the Southern Court or the Northern Court for ando of the ownership of their lands.

sen.j: 幕府は守護大名庶家や足利氏譜代から奉公衆を編成し、在京奉公を課したが、一方で守護大名は国内の在地領主（国人）に対する支配を強め、その所領に応じた軍役を課すようになった。
sen.e: The Muromachi shogunate formed Hokoshu (military guard of the shogunate) from branch families of Shugo Daimyo and hereditary vassals of Ashikaga clan and imposed service in Kyoto on them; on the other hand, Shugo Daimyo tightened control over zaichi-ryoshu (kokujin; local lord) in their provinces and imposed military services on them according to their shoryo.
sen.cmt: 話題が先の鎌倉時代から室町時代に移ったので、「幕府」を「室町幕府」と訳出しました。

sen.e: As the strategy changed from one-to-one duels by horsemen to party battle and army battle, the military service had been based on the area of shoryo and the crop yields.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代、室町時代は時に応じて課せられ、一定の基準はなかったが、江戸幕府においてはこれを一定させた。
sen.e: The military service was not based on a certain standard and imposed for each occasion in the Kamakura period and the Muromachi period; and the Edo shogunate standardized that.

sen.j: 1615年（元和 (日本)元年）、大坂の陣にあたり、徳川秀忠は軍令を発して諸軍の部署を定めるとともに軍役を定めてこれを課した。
sen.e: In 1615, upon fighting Osaka Natsu no Jin (Summer Battle of Osaka), Hidetada TOKUGAWA issued the military order to appoint armies to their posts and to define the military service and imposed them on the army.
